alert.note: Alert for Big Horn; Carbon; Park; Stillwater; Sweet Grass (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued June 18 at 1:58PM MDT by NWS Billings
info.description: ...Heavy rain may increase river and stream flows Sunday into Monday... A weather system moving across the region is expected to bring periods of showers and thunderstorms across the Beartooth Mountains and foothills Sunday and Sunday evening. Some of the thunderstorms could produce locally heavy rainfall. The best chance of heavy rainfall from thunderstorms is around midday Sunday with another round in the later afternoon and early evening. With area waterways already running high with snowmelt, this additional precipitation may push some rivers and streams close to bankfull early this week. Please note, if any flooding occurs, it is not expected to compare at all to the recent serious flooding in the area last week. Widespread heavy precipitation is not expected, so the location of any local heavy rainfall that occurs Sunday will determine which rivers and streams see notable rises. Smaller streams and creeks in the foothills are the most susceptible to flooding during these types of events in the snowmelt runoff season. That said, the Clarks Fork of Yellowstone at Edgar and at Belfry may see levels approach flood stage by Monday, with some minor flooding possible in adjacent low lying areas. This is also true of the Stillwater River near Absarokee. Those with interests along area waterways should continue to monitor water levels and use extra caution when near rivers and low lying areas. Bank erosion will make shorelines unstable. Do not walk near stream banks as the underlying soil may be eroded. Stay tuned to the forecast for your area. Please report any flooding to local law enforcement and have them relay the report to the National Weather Service.
